titleInfo.title: McKinley High School Oral History Project: Old South Baton Rouge Social Organizations
titleInfo.subTitle: Keith Douglas oral history interview, 2001

name.description: "Keith ""Cartoonman"" Douglas was born in 1952 in Natchez, Miss. He grew up in New Orleans, attended elementary and high school there, and was interested in art from an early age. He attended Xavier University in New Orleans where he studied under printmaker John Scott. After graduating, he taught art in public schools in New Orleans (Alfred C. Priestly High School) and Baton Rouge (McKinley High School and Southeast Middle School) for many years. He is a successful artist known for his cartoons and caricatures."

mods.note: Louisiana State University Libraries Special Collections (http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special)
mods.accessCondition: Physical rights are retained by the LSU Libraries. Copyright is retained by Louisiana State University in accordance with U.S. copyright laws.

"E-mail lsudiglib@lsu.edu with questions or comments. See instructions for ordering reprints of this audio here: http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special/services/duplication.html Mention the ""Item number"" or ""Item URL"" in your request. "
mods.abstract: Douglas talks extensively about his creative process and concepts, including his cartoon characters, his caricature business, his ideas for children's books and toys, and plans for films and TV shows. He recalls weather and sports-related artwork he completed for New Orleans broadcasters Hap Glaudi and Bob Breck. Inspired by his father's example of turning ideas into money, Douglas is a powerhouse of plans. He compares public schools in New Orleans and Baton Rouge and details his approaches to teaching art to youth. He discusses artists in the South Baton Rouge community, his experiences as an artist there, and his concern over young people's declining appreciation of art and music.
